posts.name: edarzins
posts.cooked:
I have a question regarding PhotonVision setup, specifically the robotToCamera transform. We’re using two PV cameras (one on left side, one on right side) and one Limelight on the center front. The PV cameras are giving us incorrect pose data (as much as a meter off, and not consistent with each other). The pose results from the Limelight are correct and consistent. I suspect there’s something wrong with the robotToCamera transforms for the PV cameras, so I’m hoping that someone can verify that we’re doing that correctly or discover our error.

These are the positions of the cameras, assuming that the +x axis is pointed out the front of the robot, +y axis is to the left, and +z is up. Origin is at the center of the robot and z=0 is the floor.

Left PV Camera: 0.151, 0.319, 0.578 (meters) Right PV Camera: 0.151, -0.319, 0.578 (meters)

The left camera is pointed directly out the left side (along the +y axis), with an upward tilt of 10 degrees. The right camera is pointed directly out the right side (along the -y axis), with an upward tilt of 10 degrees.

Using these coordinates and rotations, these are the robotToCamera transforms we created:

static const auto LEFT_CAMERA_A_TF = frc::Transform3d{0.151_m, 0.319_m, 0.578_m, frc::Rotation3d(0_deg, -10_deg, 90_deg)}; static const auto RIGHT_CAMERA_A_TF = frc::Transform3d{0.151_m, -0.319_m, 0.578_m, frc::Rotation3d(0_deg, -10_deg, -90_deg)};

Thoughts? Thanks for your help!

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
Hmmmm good question. Quickly looking at the numbers, I can’t say for certain I see something obviously wrong, but agreed the symptom doesn’t feel right.

One thing we do to debug this - AdvantageScope (ships with wpilib) has an awesome 3d field viewer , and can display 3d poses/transforms/translations.

RobotCasserole2024/drivetrain/poseEstimation/drivetrainPoseTelemetry.py at main · RobotCasserole1736/RobotCasserole2024 · GitHub is an example of how we publish our camera poses (relative to the robot’s pose) - this was an awesome visual tool for verifying that software was assuming the camera location correctly.

Again, don’t feel too bad - these 3d geometry things are nearly impossible for me to debug in code, I need a visualization to think through where I messed things up.

posts.name: Curt Rozeboom
posts.cooked:
OK, something we did in our code, which I got from 6328 was to apply the rotations separately, not as a single rotation3d. There’s a function called rotateBy you can use. So do frc::Rotation3d(0,-10,0).rotateby(0,0,+/-90);

If you’re confused and tilting your head to the side at this, you maybe modeling your camera’s pose There’s more than 1 way for the camera to end up positioned -10 degrees pitched back. If it is rotated +/-90 and then pitched -10, it will resemble a confused dog tilting its head to the side and not calculate the way you want. But, if you pitch back first, then rotate 90, you should end up with the correct orientation. I could be wrong, but try it and see. Can’t hurt.

posts.name: gcschmit
posts.cooked: I assume the C++ API handles units for you, but we’ve had issues when we’ve passed a value in degrees when the Java constructor expects a value in radians.

posts.name: edarzins
posts.cooked: Thanks for the tip! Displaying the pose and transform in AdvantageScope verified that it is correct.

posts.name: Rishivarshil Nelakurti
posts.cooked: Doesn’t Photonvision already handle the order of rotations by default when supplying the transform3D?
